article:
'Achieved status' is a concept developed by the anthropologist Ralph Linton
denoting a social position that a person can acquire on the basis of merit; it
is a position that is earned or chosen. It is the opposite of ascribed status.
It reflects personal skills, abilities, and efforts. Examples of achieved status
are being an Olympic athlete, being a criminal, or being a college professor.

Status is important sociologically because it comes with a set of rights,
obligations, behaviors, and duties that people occupying a certain position are
expected or encouraged to perform. These expectations are referred to as roles.
For instance, the role of a "professor" includes teaching students, answering
their questions, being impartial, and dressing appropriately.
headings: Achieved status in stratification systems around the world
